reviewText:
Back in the day I was dissapointed Fallout Tactics wasn't a 'real' roleplaying game like Fallout 1 & 2. Being a huge fan of the series I still gave this game a try and I wasn't dissapointed to say the least.

Fallout Tactics, like the name already says, is a tactical game in the Fallout universe. You start by creating your main character and give him/her the skills you prefer. You start out with 2 other squad members and as the game progresses your squad members level up so you can adjust their skills like all (PC) Fallout games. After each mission you enter the worldmap to go to different locations like you're bunker where you can recruit new squad members and/or buy/sell equipment. Squad members can ofcourse die and won't return (unless you load your savegame).

What sets Fallout Tactics apart from other tactical games for me:
1. The variety of enemies. Sometimes you'll be battling Bugs, the other time you will be facing Super Mutants and several other enemies I won't name here (spoilers). Every enemy calls for a different approach.
2. The variety of missions. Sometimes you will have to rescue people, sometimes you have to do an escort mission. Also in most missions you've got a vehicle at your disposal.
3. The variety of weapons. Fallout Tactics has a huge range of weapons, both realistic and unrealistic but they all fit in the game nicely.
4. The use of skills in a game. Lockpicking, Healing, Defusing... it's all there.
5. Different 'races'. Your squad may also contain different kinds of races like ghouls and Super Mutants. All of them ofcourse have their own speciality/skills.
6. Gameplay. The tactical combat just works really well in this game as a tactical game should obviously. Everytime you make a clean kill feels very good.
7. Graphics. The graphics have aged very well in my opinion. Blood and gore is ofcourse included and every kill feels satisfying.
8. Last but not least; The Fallout universe.

Simply put in my opinion Fallout Tactics is still the best tactical game out there. Although I have to admit it's partially due the Fallout universe. I have played the XCOM series and Jagged Alliance and this game is still number 1 in my book.

reviewText:
Fallout Tactics emphasizes tactical combat and strategy but limited interactions with non-player characters, but they can still be traded with. Instead of towns, Fallout Tactics centers around Brotherhood bunkers and missions. The bunkers serve as a central point for the Brotherhood, and players can obtain the services of quartermasters, mechanics, personnel yeomen, and medics.

Combat in Fallout Tactics is a bit more complicated than the previous two Fallout games. Unlike those, which featured an individual turn-based system, Fallout Tactics features three combat types: Continuous Turn-Based (everyone can act at the same time, and action points are regenerated at a rate based on Agility), Individual Turn-Based (used in the original games) and Squad Turn-Based (each turn is given to a squad and include the ability to change stance, modifiers for height, and setting sentry modes).

Fallout Tactics is also the first of the Fallout games to feature a multi-player mode.
In this mode, each player controls a squad of characters and faces off against opposing players. During game setup, players are granted a number of points with which to purchase squad members and gear.

Although the main character in the single player game has to be human, recruits from the brotherhood and characters in multiplayer matches can be of any of the six races featured in the game. Humans, Super Mutants, Ghouls, Deathclaws, Dogs or Humanoid Robots.

reviewText:
I had almost exclusively played turn-based strategy games or slow RTS games with empire-building, resource gathering, etc. before I saw this for sale secondhand at a very cheap price and decided to try it. Bear in mind my review is that of a rank amateur, but someone who has played this particular game all the way through several times, on Steam and off.

If there is anyone else out there like me, someone who doesn't enjoy fast-paced first-person shooter games but still wants a *little* bit of real-time pressure on your game play, this is a great game for that. The learning curve is pretty short, considering this type of game was unfamiliar to me. The post-apocalyptic setting is at time humorous and never takes itself  too seriously. By today's standards the animation is a little clunky, and graphics processing a bit cumbersome.

This was possibly the first game I've ever played where friendly fire was a real danger. At first it was frustrating that I couldn't expect my PC's to shoot around each other, but then it simply became a natural part of the tactical challenge. (Why would I ever realistically expect NOT to be injured when someone standing right behind me opens up with a .50 cal in my direction?)

For anyone working on third-person sequels to this: please do something about the ladders and stairs. Make them more  fluid and accessible. I've had many a player character shot to pieces because the computer can't figure out how to send two of them down a wide staircase at the same time!

reviewText:
Do you like the Fallout stories and world? Do you enjoy big guns and making mutants go boom?  Then this game might be for you if you are down for running a 6 man (or woman or mixed) team of soldiers in retaking the wasteland from the Mutants, ghouls, raiders and other enemies you meet along the way!

This game uses a large over world map that you can freely explore (ahla Fallout 1 and 2) and run into random encounters or just plot a point to your next objective.  Once you hit an encounter or your next objective it changes over to a 3/4th top down view of the battlefield and gives you command of your troopers.  You can either run the game in real time or in turn based (as in Fallout 1 and 2).  I've found the game much more enjoyable in the real time element.  You can for instance have a sniper climb a tower to spot enemies, then sneak a couple of other people up to either side of a door and set them to fire on anything that comes rushing out.  Once the sniper takes the first shot it's game on.

Honestly the reviews when the game came out largely panned the game but I feel like it deserves better than it got.  This is one of my favorite games.   If you like Final Fantasy Tactics or Jagged Alliance or are just a hard core Fallout fan this game is more than likely something you would enjoy.  Or as another endorsement I still own my disc copy of this game from when it came out, but I went ahead and bought it again on Steam just for convience.

The fallout series most notable feature is its dynamic choice system, in that choices you make directly and indirectly influence the world around you. This game has very little of that, so if really want a diverse range of choices that can effect you negatively and positively, then you probably won't find much here to entertain you. There is a ton of combat, so the CTB is much faster unless you get to a particularly hard part.  Even in the CTB there is plenty of tactics and positioning before you engage.  Having your squad sneak up behind a barrier in a crawl, then have them simultaneously pop up and burst AK47 fire and shotgun blasts into the enemies face is great fun.  Get caught off guard and find yourself swarmed, don't panic, simply hit Return and enter turn based.\n\nThe campaign is interesting, and all the leveling and character customization from the Fallout RPGs (1/2)  is here.  Throw in the scavenging feel of a post apocalypse world and you can't lose.  Strongly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Let's start this review off by saying that this game has a very mixed reputation, and for a very good reason.

Fallout Tactics isn't like its forefathers Fallout 1 and Fallout 2. Fallout Tactics is a strategy game, and unlike its forefathers, has no speech skill, no major RPG elements, and more straightforward, action based gameplay. It has a very unique story, and is so far the only Fallout game that has its setting in the Midwestern United States.

Fallout Tactics has voiceacted dialog, unlike Fallout 1 and 2. Fallout Tactics also offers four difficulty settings, Easy, Normal, Hard, and Insane. Easy is about what you would expect, easy, it makes the game very very easy and significantly more easygoing. Normal isn't much different, but it too offers a more story and action based game than the two harder difficulties. Hard is a minor step up from Normal, forcing you to play more adaptively, and sparringly with your supplies, as vendors either don't restock, or you have to complete a mission for them to, making supplies very restricted if you waste them. Insane is exactly what you would expect, insane. It's borderline impossibly hard if you play with Tough Guy Mode turned on, which I will touch on in a second. Insane mode drops your accuracy by a flat 20%, halves your average damage, curbs your chance to get criticals to extremely low, doubles enemy damage, resistence, accuracy, and worst of all, the enemy will get critical hits with frightening frequency. Strategy is everything on Insane. Your supplies become even more limited, and you will die many many many times, which makes Tough Guy even more bitter.

Tough Guy Mode makes it so you can only save when you are in a bunker, which makes Mission 1 extremely frustrating and bitter. You start off not in a bunker, with no autosave for the character you made, meaning if you die, you're going to have to remake your character all over again. Some people would say that's a very poor design choice, and I'm inclined to agree. Tough Guy Mode is something I have only ever played Fallout Tactics with turned on, extra difficulty and in this case, a Resident Evil style restrictive save system appeals to my nostalgia for difficulty driven older games. It's not too frustrating on all 3 of the easier difficulties, but on Insane, it's definitely going to make you angry once or twice per level, because there are going to be more than a few occassions in which you're going to either lose a character, or die and have to restart, due to bad luck with criticals or missing a shot you desperately needed to hit.

Fallout Tactics also comes with an editor which you can use to mod and edit the game yourself, and it's extremely well made, and isn't hard at all to learn how to use. Among the few things you can do with it, you can remedy the frustration of Mission 1 on Tough Guy Mode by checking a box in the editor that registers Mission 1 as a bunker" which allows you to save after you make your character

reviewText:
Fallout Tactics is known as the black sheep of the series. For a variety of reasons, some of them justified. This game wasn't designed by Black Isle, instead it was licensed off to third party studios.

Now what I should state is what this game isn't. Fallout Tactics doesn't feature any towns and the game's story is mostly mission based with breaks inbetween to visit Brotherhood of steel bunkers. It also takes place in Illinois, so the original Fallout continuity is also slightly butchered.

However, Tactics is an isometric turn based tactical shooter where you control a squad of soldiers. Your squad is entirely customizeable and all level up like you do. Later on in the game you get access to more unique party members like Super Mutants and Deathclaws. The Tactics in general are very pronounced in this game, and it is very rewarding to complete a mission.

In general I believe it mostly got hate because of the dumbed down spin off nature of the game. But if you go into it not expecting the Fallout 3 we were promised before Black Isle bit the dust, you'll find yourself a fairly decent tactical shooter for a good price.

Fallout Tactics has a special place in my gaming library. I probably have about a dozen play throughs under my belt since it was originally released and I still keep coming back to it. Sure it's a little buggy and poorly optimized and doesn't have half the depth of Fallout 1 or 2 but it's just such a well constructed tactical game.

The game world and story line is huge and well thought out with balanced map design and tons of little interactive set pieces in every encounter. You can play this game different every time as even the smallest mistakes or extra achievements in a mission have an effect on the final outcome.

It's a beautiful end of the isometric Fallout games and it may not be a real" Fallout game in some senses it definitely still has the soul."

What can I really say about this gem of a game?

It is certainly an acquired taste, and often people find it slow to start. That's because it is slow to start.

If you like a gritty unforgiving micromanagement RTS this is something you should look into.
One of the things that stood out to me is the insane difficult (notably for psychopaths) and the intense amounts of gore you can see.

The first time I opened this game I left it for a while as it didn't appeal to me- the controls weren't what I was used to since I played a lot of Fallout 1 and 2, and the slow start was unattractive. Once I figured out what I was doing though, the game quickly grew on me.

-Charisma
It is possible to pass the game with 1 charisma with very little penalties, but it does have a use. It affects how quickly you rank up and also opens up some recruits earlier. I read somewhere that it allows you to take two of the best recruits in the game.

I've played the game as a sniper and enjoyed this game very thoroughly.

-If you're a melee user then you might be disappointed. It seems that melee is not really that great after super mutants show up, so you're boned.

TL;DR
It's an acquired taste.
Micromanagement RTS
Melee skills non-existent after super mutants
Very fun once the controls are down
slow but strategic at times

reviewText:
Okay my least fave of the Fallout originals, if this game can even fall into that description but it is before Bethesda Oblivionised the series. Anyhow... the game does remind me of the cool Fallout 1 and 2, but with far more action and really REALLY shredded story, it is very linear with very few ways to alter the ending. You run a team of 1-6 Characters based on the Fallout 1-2 SPECIAL set up, only the first character is possible to make the rest start out as defaults and you must choose them and improve them or change them into what you want. I prefer to be the Heavy gunner on my own character as it is definatly the weapon that is easiest to cause friendly fire and keeping the rest on single sniping and short range burst to make choke points and a medic with mid-range burst weapons.

Now the game can be turned into fallout 1-2 mode, where action points are used on your turn or remain in a sort of fast forward everyone gun down everyone mode which can be highly deadly in the later parts of the game. In the Start however you will enjoy having a 6 man team with hunting rifles sniping the crap out of the enemy before they reach you and it goes fast, but when 3 hover droids with rocket launchers pop up you kinda go.... ZOMG I iz deadz. and it is true, not even power armor can guarantee survivability against a barrage of rockets fired every 2 seconds or so.... in those moments the Fallout 1-2 mode will save your well toasted behind. It strikes me that it might be this mode that made Bethesda make their own version of it for fallout 3 because it is very similar to it, you use your AP up and then it is your next guy in rotations turn, he uses his AP up and then it is the enemies turn... this does give your team a very good chance to kill whatever they are fighting with a few well placed mid-range bursts or Grenadeds.

Even if you cheat and make your main guy immortal and a 1 man army with unlimited AP there are missions that requires a team of people to succede because the targets heal each other and are spread across the map, unless all die at the same time it is impossible to succede.

The worst downside of the game is however the overland map that is annoying as hell, random encounters happens way to often, and is seriously lacking in usability, you tend to use more resources killing things than what you get.

reviewText:
Okay my least fave of the Fallout originals, if this game can even fall into that description but it is before Bethesda Oblivionised the series. Anyhow... the game does remind me of the cool Fallout 1 and 2, but with far more action and really REALLY shredded story, it is very linear with very few ways to alter the ending. You run a team of 1-6 Characters based on the Fallout 1-2 SPECIAL set up, only the first character is possible to make the rest start out as defaults and you must choose them and improve them or change them into what you want. I prefer to be the Heavy gunner on my own character as it is definatly the weapon that is easiest to cause friendly fire and keeping the rest on single sniping and short range burst to make choke points and a medic with mid-range burst weapons.

Now the game can be turned into fallout 1-2 mode, where action points are used on your turn or remain in a sort of fast forward everyone gun down everyone mode which can be highly deadly in the later parts of the game. In the Start however you will enjoy having a 6 man team with hunting rifles sniping the crap out of the enemy before they reach you and it goes fast, but when 3 hover droids with rocket launchers pop up you kinda go.... ZOMG I iz deadz. and it is true, not even power armor can guarantee survivability against a barrage of rockets fired every 2 seconds or so.... in those moments the Fallout 1-2 mode will save your well toasted behind. It strikes me that it might be this mode that made Bethesda make their own version of it for fallout 3 because it is very similar to it, you use your AP up and then it is your next guy in rotations turn, he uses his AP up and then it is the enemies turn... this does give your team a very good chance to kill whatever they are fighting with a few well placed mid-range bursts or Grenadeds.

Even if you cheat and make your main guy immortal and a 1 man army with unlimited AP there are missions that requires a team of people to succede because the targets heal each other and are spread across the map, unless all die at the same time it is impossible to succede.

The worst downside of the game is however the overland map that is annoying as hell, random encounters happens way to often, and is seriously lacking in usability, you tend to use more resources killing things than what you get.

Bottomline: story is meh okay and gameplay is meh okay. Only a true fan of the series would like it enough to beat it and feel that they did not waste time, but as it follows with Fallout 1 and 2 in a bunble it will be worth it.

reviewText: I suggest any prospective players of Fallout Tactics ignore the rose-tinted nostalgia contained in many of these positive reviews, and realize that even at the time of release Fallout Tactics had a well-deserved reputation as a mediocre knockoff of Fallout 1 and 2. At its core the game is a squad based, isometric RPG with a similar control scheme to Infinity Engine games such as Baldur's Gate and Icewind Dale, but it tries to focus almost entirely on large scale combat over the lore, exploration and storytelling that made the original two Fallout games so enjoyable. You generally use the same mechanics, weapons and abilities found in Fallout 2, and even can switch between real-time and the classic" turn based combat

reviewText:
This game is a mess.

I've had several issues with it and plenty are technical issues.
The game doesn't run well on newer operation systems and if you want to play fullscreen on windows 8, you'll have to do some glitching in order for it too work.
But even then you'll get tearing, lagging and textures popping in and out. Talking about popping in and out, if you're in the open desert and as you walk, enemies will spawn right behin where you just walked. This is especially annoying when you want to clear rooms and suddenly find out that enemies spawned as you left the room, even worse in large areas where the objective is to kill everyone and you have to backtrack to look for those that spawned after you left.

Unlike previous Fallout games, you can't see what's in a room when you're not in it. That's fine, if it wasn't so buggy. Enemies will appear and reappear in the room after several seconds of you standing inside of it, you might even just stand right infront of a enemy and have to wait for it to appear so you can kill it.

If you're in it for Fallout lore, remember that this game is only semi-cannon and also that there is barely any Fallout here. Sure there are few references to Fallout here and there, many of which are minor and uninteresting.

If you're here for the Squad-Based Combat, go elsewhere. Any interactions i've had with the rest of the squad has been unpleasant and annoying. If you're playing in turn-based mode, you'll find that the AI's turns take an insane amount of time, oddly enough, if there are no AIs in the area it still takes alot of time. I playing in real time mode and found that my teammates are more likely to kill themselves and me, rather than the enemy. I abandoned them and played mostly solo, which was more like the other Fallout games and alot more enjoyable.

The story seemed like it could be promising but the intro after you start a new game is laughably bad, so much that it's painful to watch. The general, whom you get your missions from, is an awful tough guy cliche. I wish he was muted so i didn't have to listen to him everytime i enter a new mission area. The voice acting is pretty bad and the writing doesn't help either. I especially hate the real world character pictures used for all the characters in the game. It screams low production and i think that's what this game is.
Most of the story is told through a picture book with narration but that only happens when major event occur and is honestly the most interest part of the whole thing.

Vehicle combat is a thing, it's unresponsive, the vehicle gets stuck, doesn't go where you want it to go and is very buggy. All in all, it's a terrible experience and i'd much rather just not do those missions.

I don't intend on finishing this game, it's not worth it. And i think if you want to do yourself a big favor, i would say don't buy this game.

reviewText:
Fallout Tactics is not, as many seems to think, the third fallout game. It is a spin-off, set in the time between the two original Fallouts and focusing almost entirely on the one aspect of it's predecessors that was almost universally disliked, squad combat.

As you head off into the wasteland one more time you will find some comfort in the familiar. The SPECIAL system is still in place and allows you to customize both yourself and the squad with which you are now required to do battle beside. Memories of NPC burstfiring and having Marcus in your team at all can quickly be dismissed however as your entire squad is completely under your control this time.

Battles play out in either the regular turn based mode which with a big team, big maps and lots of enemies make the game dreadfully slow at times, or a pseudo-realtime mode that lets everyone act out their turns in concert with each other. The real time mode might make some of the smaller battles fly past quicker but as it was obviously never part of the core mechanics it comes with a whole slew of problems that makes it unusable when faced with bigger enemy parties, most notably each character will only perform one action at a time and will then stand around afterwards, waiting to be told to fire off his gun for a second time.

The great writing of the old Fallout's make a return, although in a more condensed format and lots of the over the top humor from Fallout 2 is present as well making the non-combat segments of the game quite enjoyable, the non-linearity and the choice and consequence system from those games are not present however.

Graphically the game feels dated, a long time has passed since the original Fallout and not much has changed since then. The soundtrack still contains some gems and the game does succeed in places at re-creating that Fallout fell. Those instances are unfortunately quite rare.

All in all Fallout Tactics is a game that takes too much away from what is tried and true. It tries to create a new experience in a medium with which it has little familiarity and the many rookie mistakes shines through all too much. This makes this a hard game to recommend, even for a die-hard Fallout fan such as myself.

reviewText:
Now, I do enjoy this game quite a bit, but the fact remains that they've never patched some of the game-breaking bugs that can get you stuck when revisiting a special encounter - such as Bazaar Day or Phil the Nuka Cola Dude. These bugs nearly swayed my recommendation, but it doesn't quite ruin the whole game unless you're a one-save kind of person.

Another issue is the slow-paced combat when using the turn-based options, while the continuous turn-based isn't so bad, but it has its drawbacks. For instance, you might be moving two separate groups in an area and might forget another group for long enough for an enemy patrol to come by and open fire on them.

Traveling on the world map is another bad experience due to the frequent, almost constant barrage of random encounters. This makes it absolutely vital to level somebody's Outdoorsman skill to 100 or more to give you the option to skip them and continue your journey.

It's a decent game, but it has a few nagging drawbacks that keep it from comparing to the first two Fallout games. If you play it, keep these things in mind, as they're quite frustrating at times.

reviewText:
I play offline often so my hours arent always tracked but I've played about 35-40 hours in-game now (if I had to guess) and I love it! I began the Fallout series with Fallout 3 and then New Vegas - without every playing their predecessors.

Fallout Tactics BOS has a no holds bar approach to dialogue and gore (also seen in rest of the series). Not only does it provide interesting and realistic conversations and situations but the story is so vastly complete that it kicks your adventurous spirit and curiosity in to over-drive. I never exit the game feeling like i hadnt accomplished something. And I always want more.

If you love the Fallout Universe and havent played Tactics, PLEASE give it a whirl! You will not be disappointed (Unless you're just an FPS junkie). And even if you're unfamiliar with Fallout but you enjoy games like; Exile, Avernum, Geneforge, D&D, Shadowrun, XCOM, Baldurs Gate or other various RPG's in that catergory, this is the game you've been waiting for!

Side Notes:
1. Expect some inventory micro-managing if you HAVE to have EVERY peice of loot, like myself.
2. Don't use melee! Stick to unarmed if you want close combat. 100x better.
3. You don't have to use a perk when you first get it. If you hit cancel you can use it later when a better perk becomes available.
4. Don't bother with Turn-Based mode, it's pretty buggy. It may help during hostage situations but Real-Time mode is smooth.

Lastly... Save Save SAVE!!!

10/10 All day!

reviewText:
Not mayny folk out there like this game, for varying reasons... the hardcore Fallout fans refuse it because it lacks a solid 'character cenetric' story RPG.

The fans of the new Fallout games probably dislike this because of it's archaic graphics (or its less than forgiving controls& interface)

But I really like this game, it falls neatly in a place between the original Fallout games and Jagged Allience 2, I love both of these things and this game merges the best of both.

I've played through probably 4 times before I even bought it on steam, my CD version has the scratches to prove its worth to me... And I'll not shy away from playing it again. There's something about the management of a team of guys coupled with turn based (or faux real-time) combat that ticks all the boxes in my brain.

If you ever enjoyed Jagged Allience 2, this is certianly worth a go.

Pros:
- quite a big game.
- nicely written (and in keeping with Fallout originals) lore.
- nice squad options and varience.
- I personally like the controls.

cons:
- tricky to get into
- some lore breaks the Fallout concept :(
- unforgiving view ( I wish i could rotate the screen at times)
- old graphics (and it shows!)
- you likely need a 'workaround' to play it on most modern PC
